The Right to be Forgotten in Federated Learning: An Efficient Realization with Rapid Retraining

Yi Liu1, Lei Xu2, Xingliang Yuan3, Cong Wang1, and Bo Li4 The authors have provided public access to their code and data at github.com/yiliucs/federated-unlearning. 1City University of Hong Kong; 2Nanjing University of Science and Technology;
3Monash University; 4The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.
{yiliu247, congwang}@cityu.edu.hk, xuleicrypto@gmail.com, xingling.yuan@monash.edu, bli@cse.ust.hk
Abstract

In Machine Learning, the emergence of the right to be forgotten gave birth to a paradigm named machine unlearning, which enables data holders to proactively erase their data from a trained model. Existing machine unlearning techniques focus on centralized training, where access to all holdersâ€™ training data is a must for the server to conduct the unlearning process. It remains largely underexplored about how to achieve unlearning when full access to all training data becomes unavailable. One noteworthy example is Federated Learning (FL), where each participating data holder trains locally, without sharing their training data to the central server. In this paper, we investigate the problem of machine unlearning in FL systems. We start with a formal definition of the unlearning problem in FL and propose a rapid retraining approach to fully erase data samples from a trained FL model. The resulting design allows data holders to jointly conduct the unlearning process efficiently while keeping their training data locally. Our formal convergence and complexity analysis demonstrate that our design can preserve model utility with high efficiency. Extensive evaluations on four real-world datasets illustrate the effectiveness and performance of our proposed realization.

I Introduction

The paradigm of â€œMachine Unlearningâ€ [1] has attracted much attention recently. It has emerged from â€œthe right to be forgottenâ€ [2], where individuals should be entitled to the right to have their private data removed from public directories. This regulated requirement has also set off a privacy-aware technology reform in the context of Machine Learning. From a high-level point of view, the techniques of machine unlearning enable data holders to proactively erase their data from a trained model that memorizes the data. Most of the existing machine unlearning techniques focus on the centralized settingÂ [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10], where all the training data samples are collected to a server, and later specific samples are requested to be erased via unlearning. However, this setting can be somewhat limited in practice because not all data holders are willing to share data for training due to increasing privacy concerns.

In this paper, we investigate the problem of machine unlearning in a more practical scenario, where data holders are collaboratively performing training and unlearning without sharing raw data. In particular, we target Federated Learning (FL) [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17], a widely adopted privacy-aware collaborative learning framework. In FL, data holders train a model from their local data samples, and the server only aggregates data holdersâ€™ local model updates for data privacy considerationsÂ [18]. Despite the above benefit, not allowing the sharing of raw data also poses unique challenges for unlearning in FL.

To erase data samples from a trained FL model, a straightforward approach is to simply train a new model from scratch on the remaining dataset (i.e., excluding the samples that need to be erased) following the original training procedure of FL. However, this approach would be neither practical nor economical for real-world models that are usually trained for weeks from massive training samples. Existing studies on centralized machine unlearningÂ  [8, 5, 6, 7] are not directly applicable because they have to access the raw data during unlearning, which is prohibitive in FL in the first place. Very recently, Liu et al. [19] proposed an approach called FedEraser that aims to address this problem in FL. Unfortunately, this approach has two drawbacks. First, FedEraser only initiates the unlearning algorithm among the clients that request data removal. Namely, other clientsâ€™ models still hold the contributions of the data to be removed, which will later be aggregated in a global model. Second, their proposed algorithm utilizes the latest rounds of local model updates to approximate the current unlearned model update. However, the data samples to be removed can be used for training from the very beginning, and the utilized model updates may still consist of the trace of those samples.

Erasing data samples from a trained FL model is non-trivial. To better understand the problem, we first identify two unique challenges in the context of FL as follows.

(C1.) Training is interactive. In FL, the client holds data locally and iteratively exchanges model updates with the server to learn a shared global model. In this context, it is challenging for the central server to erase the contribution of the client data to the model. The key reason is that the client continuously shares the knowledge learned from the local dataset with other clients via model aggregation.

(C2.) Training is incremental. Training in FL is also an incremental procedure in which any given local update reflects all previous updates that occurred on the client. Suppose the global model is updated based on the local model updates that specific clients generate at a particular training round. In that case, all subsequent model updates will implicitly relate to the model updates of these clients.

Our Contributions. To address the above challenges, we deem that the best mechanism so far for data erasure in FL is to perform retraining among all the data holders, so as to completely eliminate the contributions of data samples to be removed. Then the key problem is how to design a rapid retraining approach in FL while preserving model utility. Specifically, we propose a distributed Newton-type model update algorithm, which follows the Quasi-Newton method [20] and utilizes the first-order Taylor expansion to approximate the loss function trained by the local optimizer on the remaining dataset, i.e., the one excludes the removed data samples. To further reduce the cost of retraining, we employ diagonal empirical Fisher Information Matrix (FIM) [21] to efficiently and accurately approximate the inverse Hessian vector to avoid the expensive cost of directly calculating it. To preserve model utility, we apply the momentum technique to the diagonal empirical FIM to alleviate the error caused by the approximation techniques and make the model convergence faster and more stable. The contributions of this paper are listed as follow:

  • â€¢

    We formally define the data erasure problem in federated learning and propose an efficient and effective retraining algorithm. Our proposed algorithm is model agnostic and can naturally be integrated to the framework of FL.

  • â€¢

    We customize a retraining algorithm based on the diagonal empirical FIM for FL, by observing the first-order Taylor expansion of the loss function during the unlearning process. We introduce an adaptive momentum technique to reduce approximation errors in retraining.

  • â€¢

    We conduct a formal convergence analysis over our proposed algorithm and analyze the time and space complexity. Theoretical analysis results show that our algorithm converges to the true optimization path of the strongly convex objectives.

  • â€¢

    We implement our design and conduct extensive experiments over four datasets in terms of the ability to achieve unlearning, efficiency, model performance, and parameter sensitivity. Compared to the baseline retraining, our approach can achieve a speedup of 9.1Ã—9.1\times with an accuracy loss of 2.235 Ã—10âˆ’3absentsuperscript103\times 10^{-3} on the large dataset CelebA.

II Related Work

Our work is related to a line of studies on machine unlearning. Based on the methodology and target problems, they can be classified into two categories, exact unlearning methods and approximate unlearning methods.

Exact Unlearning Methods. These methods are designed to achieve machine unlearning in such a way that the produced models are effectively the same as the ones obtained with retraining. To be specific, they introduce a notion called certified data erasure, which is a theoretical guarantee that a model from which data is removed cannot be distinguished from a model that never observed the data to begin with. Following this objective, some existing work [22, 23, 6, 24, 5] proposes unlearning methods for simple machine models, such as linear regression models, Random Forests models, and kğ‘˜k-nearest neighbors models. However, these unlearning methods are not suitable for complex nonlinear models (e.g., deep learning models) [8]. On the other hand, these designs cannot directly be applied in FL, because they cannot erase the unlearned data samplesâ€™ contributions (i.e., learned knowledge) shared by the clients in FL.

Approximate Unlearning Methods. Intuitively, these methods aim to achieve higher efficiency of machine unlearning through the relaxation of the effectiveness and certifiability requirementsÂ [5, 25]. Most of themÂ [10, 3, 8] ask the server to utilize historical gradients and model weights to efficiently approximate the gradients in the unlearning process. However, recent work [26, 27] demonstrated that an attacker (e.g., a malicious central server) can exploit the clientâ€™s local gradients to implement an attack to reconstruct the private training samples of the client. Therefore, the above methods may expose the clientâ€™s private data to the server and are not desired for FL. A recent designÂ [19] is closely related to our work, which aims to design an efficient retraining algorithm called FedEraser to achieve unlearning in FL. As mentioned before, this work cannot fully erase the contributions of data samples to be removed from the trained model. Besides, it follows the above approximate methods, where the server utilizes cached historical gradients from clients to approximate the current unlearned gradient, which may lead to serious privacy leakage on data holdersâ€™ data samples, e.g., gradient leakage attacks [26, 15].

III-B Machine Unlearning Pipeline

In the context of ML, the emergence of the right to be forgotten gave birth to a paradigm called machine unlearning, which enriches the life cycle of traditional ML pipelines by offering data deletion functions. To be specific, machine unlearning pipelines include how the model is trained, employed for inference, incremental update, and conducted a series of data deletions, while retraining from scratch [28].

Training Stage: In the machine unlearning setting, we consider a service provider ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and Kğ¾K data owners, where Kğ¾K data owners share the data with the service provider to form a initial training dataset ğ’Ÿ=ğ’Ÿiâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tğ’Ÿsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}_{init}. Notably, the data owner can initiate a data deletion request to the service provider at any time during the life cycle of the pipeline to perform data deletion. Therefore, the initial training dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is not always constant, which is a subset of the initial training dataset, i.e., ğ’ŸâŠ†ğ’Ÿiâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tğ’Ÿsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\mathcal{D}}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{init}. Specifically, if service provider deletes some data samples from ğ’Ÿiâ€‹nâ€‹iâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{init}, thus, we have: ğ’Ÿâ†ğ’Ÿ\ğ’Ÿmâ†ğ’Ÿ\ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š{\mathcal{D}}\leftarrow\mathcal{D}\backslash{\mathcal{D}_{m}}, where ğ’Ÿmsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{D}_{m} is the deleted data subset. So we use ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} represents the currently available training dataset. The loss or objective function for a general machine learning model is defined as:

IV Problem definition

IV-A Formalizing the Problem of Federated Unlearning

We now formalize the data erasure problem in FL. In our setting, the server ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} controls the whole training process by collecting and aggregating model updates uploaded by the clients and these clients ğ’={C1,C2,â€¦,Ck},kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,K}formulae-sequenceğ’subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾{\mathcal{C}}=\{{C_{1}},{C_{2}},\ldots,{C_{k}}\},k\in\{1,\ldots,K\} hold different local datasets ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\mathcal{D}_{k}}. In particular, we enable the client to have the control to erase data, i.e., the client can request the server to delete some specific data samples. First, we introduce the concepts of federated data deletion operation. Here, we use the term â€œlearned clientâ€ to refer to those clients that have not performed data erasure, and the term â€œunlearned clientâ€ to refer to those clients that perform data erasure. We assume that there are unlearned clients Cku={C1â€²,C2â€²,â€¦,Ckuâ€²},kuâˆˆ{1,â€¦,K}\kcformulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ¶1â€²superscriptsubscriptğ¶2â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢â€²subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢\1â€¦ğ¾subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘{C_{{k_{u}}}}=\{{C_{1}^{\prime}},{C_{2}^{\prime}},\ldots,{C_{{k_{u}}}^{\prime}}\},{k_{u}}\in\{1,\ldots,K\}\backslash{k_{c}} that initiate deletion requests to the server, where kcsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘k_{c} is the index of learned client set Ckcsubscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘C_{k_{c}}. Note that when kc=0subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘0k_{c}=0, it is a special case such that all clients initiate deletion requests to the server.

By Definition 1, we formalize the problem of federated unlearning as a game between two entities: the service provider ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and the client set ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. The service provider can be a central aggregator that collects model updates from various clients, where each client Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} holds different local dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\mathcal{D}_{k}}. Service providers use the collected model updates to update and obtain the FL model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*}. Any unlearned client CkuâŠ†ğ’subscriptğ¶subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢ğ’C_{k_{u}}\subseteq\mathcal{C} can revoke the contribution of his data ğ’Ÿkuâˆˆ{Î©}i=1Rksuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptÎ©ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}\in\{\Omega\}_{i=1}^{{R_{k}}} to Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} by using the specified unlearning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}.

To this end, the service provider has to erase the clientâ€™s data contribution and retrain any trained global models Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} to produce Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u}, that is, the contribution of the data ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} is not in the Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} model. It is conceivable that the parameters of Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} and Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} are similar (despite stochasticity in learning), and it is desired for their performance (in terms of test accuracy) to be comparable. However, the fact that model Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} was obtained by training on the remaining dataset from scratch provides a certificate to the data owner that their data share was indeed removed. Certified data erasure is defined as a theoretical guarantee that a model from which data is removed cannot be distinguished from a model that never observed the data to begin with. This conveys a very strong notion of privacy. Therefore, our goal is to make service providers revoke the contribution of specified data samples to the global model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} while maintaining this modelâ€™s performance. The federated unlearning problem is defined as follows:

Definition 2.

(Federated Unlearning). Let Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} denote the global model produced by the federated learning pipeline, and Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} denote the global model produced by the federated unlearning pipeline. For a given threshold Îµâ©¾0ğœ€0\varepsilon\geqslant 0, the federated unlearning problem is defined as: there exists an unlearning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} that makes the following equation hold:

â€–Tâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ—)âˆ’Tğ’œâ€‹(Ï‰u)â€–â©½Îµ,normğ‘‡superscriptğœ”subscriptğ‘‡ğ’œsuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢ğœ€||T({\omega^{*}})-{T_{\mathcal{A}}}({\omega^{u}})||\leqslant\varepsilon, (4)

where Tâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘‡â‹…T(\cdot) denotes the distribution of models learned using unlearning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} and Îµğœ€\varepsilon is a small positive number. ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} achieves unlearning when these two distributions are Îµğœ€\varepsilonâ€“identical. In other words, in our work, this evidence (i.e., the output of unlearning algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}) takes the form of a training algorithm, which if implemented correctly, guarantees that the parameter distributions of Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} and Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} are Îµğœ€\varepsilonâ€“identical.

IV-B Goals of Federated Unlearning

As discussed in Section III-B, the simple and effective way to achieve federated unlearning is to retrain the global model from scratch on the remaining training dataset. However, such a method is unrealistic for an FL system due to large computing resources and communication overhead. Moreover, to comply with data regulations such as GDPR [2] for continuous data deletion requests, service providers need to retrain the global model frequently. In this paper, we consider this method as a baseline method to compare with our solution. To this end, our proposed solution needs to meet the following goals:

(G1.) Zero Contribution Guarantees: Similar to the baseline, any new unlearning solution should ensure that the erased data has zero contribution to the unlearned model, i.e., the erased data does not influence the model parameters.

(G2.) Privacy Guarantee: Any new unlearning solution should maintain the privacy of the client in the FL settings. Any attacker, including the server, cannot easily utilize gradient information to implement gradient leakage attacks [26].

(G3.) Comparable Accuracy: It is conceivable that there is a trade-off between the performance of the unlearning solution and the accuracy of the model, which indicates that the accuracy of the model would decrease. Even if there is no component of the approach that explicitly promotes high accuracy, any unlearning solution should strive to introduce a small accuracy gap in comparison to the baseline for any number of data samples unlearned.

(G4.) Reduced Retraining Time: Additionally, no matter how many data samples need to be unlearned, any new unlearning solution should be faster than the baseline (or other state-of-the-art unlearning approaches). Namely, any new unlearning solution should not introduce additional computation and communication overhead to the original training procedure, which is already expensive [1].

(G5.) Model Agnostic: The unlearning solution should be general, which means that it can be applied to any model. It should also provide the aforementioned guarantees for the system settings of varying nature and complexity [1, 6].

V Our Design

V-A Federated Unlearning Pipeline

In this section, we present a federated unlearning pipeline, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Specifically, the pipeline includes three stages: training stage, inference stage, and unlearning stage. The training stage and the inference stage is the same as those in FL systems (refer to Section III-A for details). The main difference from FL is that this pipeline adds the two functions, i.e., data deletion and rapid retraining, both of which are included in the unlearning stage. Thus, the details of the unlearning stage are as follows:

Unlearning Stage: (a) Data Deletion: Assuming that the kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u}-th unlearned client initiates several data deletion requests ğ’°k={u1,u2,â€¦,uRk}subscriptğ’°ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¢1subscriptğ‘¢2â€¦subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜\mathcal{U}_{k}=\{u_{1},u_{2},\ldots,u_{R_{k}}\} to the server before the start of the tğ‘¡t-th round of training, these clients need to perform data deletion operations, where the remaining local dataset is denoted as ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}. (b) Rapid Retraining: Then all clients execute the proposed unlearning algorithm (see below for more details) on the remaining local dataset ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} to achieve unlearning. Specifically, to eliminate the influence of unlearned data samples on the FL model, we perform a retrain operation to make the model forget the knowledge represented by these unlearned data samples. In this context, the naive solution (i.e., retraining from scratch) is to apply mini-batch stochastic gradient descent (SGD) directly over the remaining local training dataset ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} (we use Ï‰tkusuperscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢\omega_{t}^{k_{u}} to denote the corresponding model parameter), i.e., for kğ‘˜k-th client, the loss function can be defined as follows:

Fkuâ€‹(Ï‰)=1Bâˆ’Î”â€‹Btâ€‹âˆ‘(xi,yi)âˆˆğ’Ÿkuâ„“iâ€‹(Ï‰),subscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢ğœ”1ğµÎ”subscriptğµğ‘¡subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢subscriptâ„“ğ‘–ğœ”{F_{k_{u}}}(\omega)=\frac{1}{{B-\Delta B_{t}}}\sum\limits_{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}{{\ell_{i}}(\omega)}, (5)

where BğµB is the mini-batch size and Î”â€‹BtÎ”subscriptğµğ‘¡{\Delta{B_{t}}} is the size of the subset removed from the tğ‘¡t-th mini-batch. Thus, each client updates its local model by using: Ï‰t+1ku=Ï‰tkuâˆ’Î·Bâˆ’Î”â€‹Btâ€‹âˆ‘(xi,yi)âˆˆğ’Ÿkuâˆ‡Fkâ€‹(Ï‰tu),superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢ğœ‚ğµÎ”subscriptğµğ‘¡subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡ğ‘¢\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{\eta}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}\sum\limits_{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}{\nabla{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{u})}, where Î·ğœ‚\eta is the learning rate. After executing the local unlearning step, all clients upload model updates to the server so that the server can aggregate these updates to obtain a new unlearned global model. Thus, we have the following execution step. (c) Aggregation: Recall that, to achieve unlearning, all unlearned clients and all learned clients perform local retraining and upload the updates of the unlearned model to the server. Then the server uses the aggregation rules to aggregate the model updates of the unlearned client and other clients. Such an operation can meet the goals G1 and G2. Suppose we use the classic aggregation rule (i.e., FedAvg) to aggregate these updates, the formal definition of this aggregation rule is as follows:

Ï‰t+1u=1Kcâ€‹âˆ‘pkcâ€‹âˆ‘kcpkcâ€‹Ï‰tkc+1Kuâ€‹âˆ‘pkuâ€‹âˆ‘kupkuâ€‹Ï‰tku.superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡1ğ‘¢1subscriptğ¾ğ‘subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘1subscriptğ¾ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢subscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢\omega_{t+1}^{u}=\frac{1}{{{K_{c}}\sum{{p_{{k_{c}}}}}}}\sum\limits_{{k_{c}}}{{p_{{k_{c}}}}\omega_{t}^{{k_{c}}}}+\frac{1}{{{K_{u}}\sum{{p_{{k_{u}}}}}}}\sum\limits_{{k_{u}}}{{p_{{k_{u}}}}\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}}. (6)

Note that user-defined aggregation rules can also be used in our pipeline, which do not affect the operations of it.

V-B Federated Rapid Retraining

Obviously, the baseline is a time-consuming and resource-consuming unlearning solution, which is undesirable for real-world large FL systems. This motivates us to seek a time-saving and energy-efficient rapid retraining solution. To this end, we follow the Quasi-Newton methods [20] and use the first-order Taylor approximation technique to propose an efficient method. Specifically, for the kğ‘˜k-th client, let âˆ‡Fkuâ€‹(Ï‰)=0âˆ‡subscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢ğœ”0\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega})=0 around Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*}, we obtain:

âˆ‡Fkuâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ—)+Hkuâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ—)â€‹(Ï‰uâˆ’Ï‰âˆ—)â‰ˆ0,âˆ‡subscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptğœ”subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptğœ”superscriptğœ”ğ‘¢superscriptğœ”0\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})+{H_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})({\omega^{u}}-{\omega^{*}})\approx 0, (7)

where Ï‰u=argâ¡minâ€‹âˆ‡Fkuâ€‹(Ï‰)superscriptğœ”ğ‘¢âˆ‡subscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢ğœ”{\omega^{u}}=\arg\min\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}(\omega) is a unique global minimum (i.e., global optimal unlearned model), Hkuâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ—)=âˆ‡2Fkuâ€‹(Ï‰âˆ—)subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptğœ”superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ¹subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptğœ”{H_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})={\nabla^{2}}{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}}) is the Hessian matrix, and Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} is a minimizer for Fkâ€‹(Ï‰)subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜ğœ”F_{k}(\omega). According to the first-order optimality condition, we have: Ï‰t+1ku=Ï‰tku+1Bâˆ’Î”â€‹Btâ€‹Hkuâˆ’1â€‹Î”k,superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1ğµÎ”subscriptğµğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1subscriptÎ”ğ‘˜\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}+\frac{1}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}H_{{k_{u}}}^{-1}{\Delta_{k}}, where Î”Î”\Delta is the local gradient, i.e., Î”ku=âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(Ï‰tku,ğ’Ÿku)subscriptÎ”subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\Delta_{k_{u}}=\nabla{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}), and Hku=âˆ‡2Fkâ€‹(Ï‰tku,ğ’Ÿku)subscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptâˆ‡2subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢H_{k_{u}}={\nabla^{2}}{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}). In this way, we can utilize Newton-type update strategy to efficiently achieve unlearning goals. However, the calculation of the inverse Hessian-vector is still computationally expensive. Therefore, we further explore how to efficiently calculate the inverse Hessian matrix Hkuâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1H_{k_{u}}^{-1}.

To address this problem, recent work [10, 19] uses the limited-memory Broyden Fletcher Goldfarb Shanno (L-BFGS) algorithm [29, 30, 31] by leveraging the historical parameter-gradient pair {(Ï‰tk,âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(Ï‰tk))}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡\{(\omega_{t}^{k},\nabla F_{k}(\omega_{t}^{k}))\}_{t=1}^{T} stored in the unlearned client to approximate Hkuâˆ’1superscriptsubscriptğ»subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1H_{k_{u}}^{-1} for each of Tğ‘‡T iterations. In particular, L-BFGS fits the Hessian matrix through the first mğ‘šm historical parameter-gradient pairs without explicitly constructing and storing the approximation of the Hessian matrix or its inverse matrix, and its time and space complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(mâ€‹n)ğ’ªğ‘šğ‘›\mathcal{O}(mn). Nevertheless, L-BFGS algorithms can just efficiently solve the Hessian approximation problem only when the model is small (i.e., generally the model parameter is less than 104superscript10410^{4}, but they cannot be directly applied to the setting of large models (e.g., ResNet [32]). Furthermore, if the server stores historical gradients and parameters, it will incur privacy disclosure risks [26] to the clients.

Motivated by the limitations mentioned above, we aim to answer the following question: how to efficiently approximate the inverse Hessian matrix without utilizing the historical parameter-gradient pair {(Ï‰tk,âˆ‡Fkâ€‹(Ï‰tk))}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡\{(\omega_{t}^{k},\nabla F_{k}(\omega_{t}^{k}))\}_{t=1}^{T} in FL? In this paper, we propose a low-cost Hessian approximation method, i.e., diagonal empirical Fisher Information Matrix (FIM)-based approximation method to efficiently approximate Hessian matrix. So the unlearning update rule can be rewritten as follows:

Additionly, to significantly reduce the computational complexity and storage while maintaining the accuracy of the approximator Î“Î“\Gamma, in DNN we leverage the diagonalization technique to approximate FIM [35, 36], i.e., dâ€‹iâ€‹aâ€‹gâ€‹(Î“)â‰ˆÎ“ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘”Î“Î“diag(\Gamma)\approx{\Gamma}, where dâ€‹iâ€‹aâ€‹gâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘”Î“diag(\Gamma) is the diagonal matrix of Î“Î“\Gamma. Specifically, we only need to store the diagonal elements of Î“Î“\Gamma and make all other elements zero. Although this method can approximate the Hessian matrix efficiently, it may be affected by the variance generated by the iterative update of FL, which may lead to higher approximation errors and unstable convergence. To address this issue, this paper follows the momentum techniques used in Adam [37] and RMSProp [38] to easily apply momentum to the Hessian diagonal since it can achieve more stable and faster convergence. More specifically, let GÂ¯tsubscriptÂ¯ğºğ‘¡{{\bar{G}}_{t}} denote the Hessian diagonal with momentum, and the first and second-order moments (mtsubscriptğ‘šğ‘¡m_{t} and vtsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡v_{t}) for Hessian momentum are computed as follows:

Furthermore, other normal clients perform local training, i.e., run the following update rule: Ï‰t+1ku=Ï‰tkuâˆ’1Bâ€‹mt/vt.superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1ğµsubscriptğ‘šğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¡\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{1}{B}{m_{t}}/{v_{t}}.

We present our federated rapid retraining algorithm, as shown in Algorithm 1. As seen in lines 1 to 3, all unlearned clients perform a mini-batch data deletion operation, i.e., split the deleted data into small batches of size B<=Rkğµsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘˜B<=R_{k} and sequentially for each of them. As a result, each unlearned client obtains a locally deleted dataset ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}. Such a method will result in multiple smaller second-order Fisher information correction steps, thereby obtaining a more effective FL model at the cost of efficiency. Then all clients start the unlearning stage and perform local training on the local dataset. In particular, the unlearned client performs local training on the locally deleted dataset ğ’Ÿkusuperscriptsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}, while the normal clients perform local training on the original dataset ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k}. This is described in lines 9 to 14 and lines 18 and 25. As seen in line 16, the server uses aggregation rules such as FedAvg to iteratively aggregate the model updates uploaded by the client.

Space Complexity: In the proposed algorithm, we use the diagonal technique to approximate the Fisher information matrix and update it with the mini-batch gradients. As shown in our experiments, this allows us to support fairly large models and sample sets.

VII Experiments

VII-A Experiment Setup

To evaluate the performance of our proposed design, we conduct extensive experiments on four representative public datasets. All experiments were developed using Python 3.7 and PyTorch 1.7, and executed on a server with an NVIDIA GeForce RTX2080 Ti GPU and an Intel Xeon Silver 4210 CPU.

Datasets: In this paper, we adopt four real-world image datasets for evaluations, i.e., MNIST111http://yann.lecun.com/exdb/mnist/, Fashion-MNIST222https://github.com/zalandoresearch/fashion-mnist, CIFAR-10333https://www.cs.toronto.edu/Â kriz/cifar.html, and CelebA444https://mmlab.ie.cuhk.edu.hk/projects/CelebA.html (a.k.a. Federated LEAF [42] dataset). The datasets cover different attributes, dimensions, and number of categories, as shown in Table I, allowing us to effectively explore the unlearning utility of the proposed algorithm. To simulate the real environment settings of FL, we evenly distribute the four training datasets to all clients.

Models: In this experiment, we use a simple CNN model, i.e., CNN with 2 convolutional layers followed by 1 fully connected layer for classification tasks on the MNIST dataset and Fashion-MNIST dataset, the AlexNet model for classification tasks on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and the ResNet-18 model for classification tasks on the CelebA dataset. In particular, we performed a gender classification task on the CelebA dataset.

Hyperparameters: In our design, we consider the cross-silo FL scenario. We set the number of clients K=10ğ¾10K=10, proportion of client participation q=1ğ‘1q=1, local epoch Elâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=1subscriptğ¸ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™1{E_{local}}=1, mini-batch size Bâˆˆ{128,256,512,1024,2048}ğµ12825651210242048B\in\{128,256,512,1024,2048\}, learning rate Î·=0.001ğœ‚0.001\eta=0.001, delete rate r={2%,1.5%,1%,0.5%}ğ‘Ÿpercent2percent1.5percent1percent0.5r=\{2\%,1.5\%,1\%,0.5\%\}, training round T=200ğ‘‡200T=200, the block size b=3ğ‘3b=3, and the momentum parameter Î²1=0.9subscriptğ›½10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, Î²2=0.999subscriptğ›½20.999\beta_{2}=0.999.

Federated Unlearning Pipeline: First, we follow the above hyperparameters setting to start the training stage in the FL pipeline. Then, we use the obtained model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} for inference or unlearning. Second, if the clients initiate several data erasure requests, the server will start the unlearning stage after receiving all the requests to forget the contribution of the erased data. Notably, we define the percentage of client-side deleted data to all training data as the deletion rate rğ‘Ÿr. Finally, the server reinitializes the global model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} and uses Algorithm 1 or the baseline algorithm (see below) to perform rapid retraining to obtain the new model Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u}.

Baseline: Retraining from Scratch. This method is to delete the erased training samples and to retrain the FL model from scratch by using the remaining dataset as the training dataset.

Evaluation Metrics: First, we will evaluate the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, and the speed-up of our retraining algorithm running time is defined: v=TbTuâ€‹xğ‘£subscriptTğ‘subscriptTğ‘¢xv=\frac{{{\mathrm{T}_{b}}}}{{{\mathrm{T}_{u}}}}\mathrm{x}. Second, to fairly compare model utility, we report the performance achieved by a given model relative to the performance of the baseline model. To this end, we use the Symmetric Absolute Percentage Error (SAPE) defined as: Îµs=SAPEâ€‹(Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tâˆ—,Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tu)=|Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tuâˆ’Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tâˆ—||Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tâˆ—|+|Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tu|subscriptğœ€ğ‘ SAPEğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¢ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¢\varepsilon_{s}=\mathrm{SAPE}(Acc_{test}^{*},Acc_{test}^{u})=\frac{{|Acc_{test}^{u}-Acc_{test}^{*}|}}{{|Acc_{test}^{*}|+|Acc_{test}^{u}|}}, where Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tâˆ—ğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡Acc_{test}^{*} denotes the accuracy of the model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} obtained by the baseline algorithm on the test dataset ğ’Ÿtâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{test}, and Aâ€‹câ€‹ctâ€‹eâ€‹sâ€‹tuğ´ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¢Acc_{test}^{u} denotes the accuracy of the model Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} obtained by the proposed algorithm on the same dataset.

VII-B Evaluation

Our evaluation is four-fold: (i) To show the data erasure efficiency of Algorithm 1, we report the speed-up of the proposed algorithm; (ii) To prove the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, we compare it with the baseline in terms of accuracy and SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} under different delete rates; (iii) To explore the parameter sensitivity of the proposed algorithm, we conduct extensive case studies around the parameters kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u} and BğµB. (iv) To answer whether our algorithm can effectively realize unlearning, we conduct an analysis with experimental results.

First, we evaluate the data erasure efficiency of the proposed algorithm under different deletion rates rğ‘Ÿr settings. Specifically, we fixed the number of unlearned clients ku=1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1k_{u}=1, the learning rate Î·=0.001ğœ‚0.001\eta=0.001, and batch size B=2048ğµ2048B=2048. Then, we choose the deletion rate r={2%,1.5%,1%,0.5%}ğ‘Ÿpercent2percent1.5percent1percent0.5r=\{2\%,1.5\%,1\%,0.5\%\} to explore the data erasure efficiency of Algorithm 1. As shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, we highlight the superiority of the proposed algorithm by computing the speed-up factor vğ‘£v and the running time of each round. For each dataset, it can be clearly seen that the data erasure of the proposed algorithm is always higher than that of the baseline method, which is because that our algorithm utilizes gradient information and curvature information to find a â€œbetterâ€ descent direction, thereby reducing the time for retraining. We can also see that the data erasure ability of our algorithm is more efficient on large datasets (i.e., CIFAR-10 (v=7.1â€‹xğ‘£7.1xv=7.1\mathrm{x}) and CelebA (v=9.6â€‹xğ‘£9.6xv=9.6\mathrm{x}). The reason is that if the baseline method uses mini-batch SGD to retrain on a large dataset, this requires multiple recalculations of gradient information for the same sample, which greatly increases the cost of retraining. In Fig. 3, the running time of each round of the proposed algorithm is very close to that of the baseline, which is in line with the results of the time and space complexity analysis in Section VI-B. This experiment also shows that Algorithm 1 meets the goal G4 and G5.

Second, Table II shows the model utility of Algorithm 1 and the baseline algorithm. In addition, we also report the SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} between the accuracy of the unlearned models produced by the two algorithms. Experimental results show that the performance of the proposed algorithm is comparable to that of the baseline, i.e., meet the goal G3. For example, when r=0.5%ğ‘Ÿpercent0.5r=0.5\%, the performance of Algorithm 1 on the MNIST dataset is slightly higher than the baseline. Furthermore, when we increase rğ‘Ÿr, the performance of the proposed algorithm can still be comparable to the baseline. Obviously, the baseline method achieves stable high performance at the expense of retraining costs. Although our algorithm uses diagonal empirical FIM to approximate the Hessian matrix and damages the model utility, the use of the momentum technique makes up for this shortcoming. Similarly, this shows that our method satisfies the goal G3.

Third, we report the sensitivity of Algorithm 1 to the parameters kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u} and BğµB. We use the controlled variable method to analyze the influence of the parameters kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u} and BğµB on the data erasure efficiency of the algorithm. Specifically, when we explore the influence of parameter kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u}, we fix the deletion rate r=1%ğ‘Ÿpercent1r=1\% and B=2048ğµ2048B=2048; on the contrary, when exploring the parameter BğµB, we fix the deletion rate r=1%ğ‘Ÿpercent1r=1\% and ku=1subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢1k_{u}=1. Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 present the total running time of the two algorithms, where Fig. 3 shows that kusubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘¢k_{u} has no obvious effect on speed-up; Fig. 4 shows that BğµB has a significant impact on speed-up. Recall that these experimental results are consistent with the results of the analysis of time and space complexity in Section VI-B. Notably, the unlearning efficiency of Algorithm 1 is significantly higher than the baseline method in the case of large batch size. The reason is that in this case, this algorithm can utilize more samples to compute a more accurate diagonal empirical FIM, thereby quickly realizing unlearning.

Last, we conduct an analysis with experimental results to show the data erasure effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Concretely, we assume that {(xi,yi)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\}_{i=1}^{n} is the input sample randomly sampled from the original dataset, where xiâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ’©0superscriptğœ2{x_{i}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{\sigma^{2}}), and {(xiu,yiu)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{(x_{i}^{u},y_{i}^{u})\}_{i=1}^{n} is the input sample randomly sampled from the deleted dataset, where xiuâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)similar-tosuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ’©0superscriptğœ2{x_{i}^{u}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{\sigma^{2}}). Suppose fâ€‹(xi)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–f(x_{i}) is the output of the global model Ï‰âˆ—superscriptğœ”\omega^{*} on the original dataset, and fuâ€‹(xiu)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¢superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¢f_{u}(x_{i}^{u}) is the output of the global model Ï‰usuperscriptğœ”ğ‘¢\omega^{u} after unlearning on the deleted dataset. For example, for the CelebA dataset, the SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} value of our Algorithm 1 is 9.772 Ã—10âˆ’4absentsuperscript104\times 10^{-4}, which shows that the model generated by this algorithm and the model generated by the baseline are approximately identical. Therefore, these results have shown that the proposed algorithm meets the requirements of Definition 2 and goals G1, and G2.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we present a federated unlearning algorithm, providing efficient and effective unlearning services for data holders in FL. Specifically, we leverage the first-order Taylor expansion approximation technique to customize a rapid retraining algorithm based on diagonal experience FIM. For boosting model utility, we introduce the momentum technique into the unlearning update strategy to further alleviate the negative impact caused by approximation errors. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis and experimental support for the proposed algorithm. The performance advantage of our design has been empirically proven on some medium-scale public datasets, revealing its great potential in building data deletion FL services for various applications.
